assumption: Individual personalization methods (single subject/concept) are sufficient building blocks for multi-concept generation
hypothesis: Multi-concept generation requires specialized composition techniques rather than simple combination of single-concept methods
impact: Challenges the foundation of current personalization approaches - suggests need for multi-concept-first methodologies

assumption: Attention mechanisms can be independently modified without cross-concept interference
hypothesis: Attention mechanisms exhibit significant cross-concept interference that must be explicitly addressed for multi-concept generation
impact: Requires development of attention-aware composition methods and interference mitigation strategies

assumption: LoRA weight spaces from different concepts are compatible for linear combination
hypothesis: LoRA weight spaces require contrastive alignment before combination to prevent attribute entanglement
impact: Invalidates naive weight merging approaches - necessitates sophisticated weight space alignment methods

assumption: Different concepts can be represented by separate, non-interfering embeddings
hypothesis: Semantic relationships between concepts create inevitable interference requiring explicit modeling
impact: Challenges textual inversion approaches - suggests need for relationship-aware embedding learning

assumption: Training conditions adequately reflect deployment scenarios for personalized models
hypothesis: Distribution shift between single-concept training and multi-concept deployment requires test-time adaptation
impact: Justifies training-free approaches like LoRACLR that adapt at deployment time

assumption: Contrastive learning principles don't apply to model composition problems
hypothesis: Contrastive objectives can effectively align and merge neural network weight spaces while preserving distinct representations
impact: Opens new research direction combining contrastive learning with model merging for better multi-concept generation

assumption: Multi-concept methods only need to handle 2-3 concepts effectively
hypothesis: True personalization systems require scalable composition methods handling arbitrary numbers of concepts
impact: Demands development of scalable composition frameworks beyond current 2-3 concept limitations

assumption: Qualitative evaluation is sufficient for assessing multi-concept generation quality
hypothesis: Multi-concept generation requires comprehensive quantitative evaluation frameworks measuring concept fidelity, interference, and composition quality
impact: Necessitates development of standardized evaluation protocols and metrics for systematic comparison

assumption: Multi-concept composition methods should work across different model architectures
hypothesis: Effective composition may require architecture-specific adaptations leveraging unique structural properties
impact: Suggests need for architecture-aware composition methods rather than one-size-fits-all approaches

assumption: Empirical approaches are sufficient for multi-concept composition without theoretical foundation
hypothesis: Principled theoretical frameworks are necessary for understanding and predicting concept interaction dynamics
impact: Calls for development of mathematical theories explaining concept composition in neural networks
